byline.contributor: Aurelien Breeden reported from Paris; Nicola Clark from Mobile, Ala.; and Christopher Drew from New York. Keith Bradsher and Chris Buckley contributed reporting.
byline.original: By AURELIEN BREEDEN, NICOLA CLARK and CHRISTOPHER DREW

abstract: American government officials and Boeing experts conclude object washed ashore on French island of Reunion in western Indian Ocean came from a Boeing 777 and may be debris from Malaysia Airlines Flight 370, which disappeared in March; French aviation experts are examining piece, which appears to be a wing flap, looking for serial number that would match the lost plane.
lead_paragraph: U.S. investigators concluded that an object that washed up on the shore of Réunion, an island in the Indian Ocean, came from a Boeing 777, making it likely that it was from the flight that vanished in 2014.

headline.main: Debris Is Thought to Come From Malaysia Airlines Flight 370
headline.print_headline: Debris on an Island Is Thought to Come From Malaysia Airlines Jetliner

snippet: U.S. investigators concluded that an object that washed up on the shore of Réunion, an island in the Indian Ocean, came from a Boeing 777, making it likely that it was from the flight that vanished in 2014.
